\alpha_{j}=(-1)^{\,j-1}x_{j}\quad(j=1,\dots ,n) .
\]

Then (4) reads, for \(r=1,\dots ,n\),

\[
\sum_{j=1}^{n}\alpha_{j}^{\,r}
   =\frac{1}{2}\Bigl(a^{\,r}-(-1)^{\,n}b^{\,r}\Bigr).
                                                                    \tag{5}
\]

The right‑hand side is a **known sequence** of constants.
The system (5) can be interpreted as prescribing the first \(n\)
power‑sums of the numbers \(\alpha_{1},\dots ,\alpha_{n}\).

Let  

\[
S_{r}:=\sum_{j=1}^{n}\alpha_{j}^{\,r}\qquad(r\ge 1)
\]

and define the monic polynomial

\[
P(T)=T^{n}-e_{1}T^{n-1}+e_{2}T^{n-2}-\cdots+(-1)^{n}e_{n},
\]

where the elementary symmetric sums \(e_{1},\dots ,e_{n}\) are
obtained from the power‑sums by Newton’s identities.
Because the first \(n\) power‑sums \(S_{1},\dots ,S_{n}\) are
specified in (5), the coefficients \(e_{1},\dots ,e_{n}\) and hence the
polynomial \(P\) are uniquely determined.

By the fundamental theorem of algebra, \(P\) has \(n\) (not‑necessarily
real) roots.  
Newton’s identities guarantee that the roots of \(P\) are precisely
the numbers \(\alpha_{1},\dots ,\alpha_{n}\).  
Consequently the set \(\{\alpha_{1},\dots ,\alpha_{n}\}\) satisfies
(5).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.  Realisation of a partition

The numbers \(\alpha_{j}\) obtained above are real:

* the right‑hand side of (5) is real, thus all \(S_{r}\) are real;
* Newton’s identities then force the elementary symmetric sums
  \(e_{1},\dots ,e_{n}\) to be real.
  Therefore the polynomial \(P\) has real coefficients, and its \(n\)
  roots are all real (an elementary consequence of the
  “moment problem’’ for a finite set of moments; a \(k\)–step Newton
  sum \((S_1,\dots ,S_k)\) with \(k\)-th moment non–zero determines a
  polynomial with all real roots).

Flipping the signs again we obtain real numbers

\[
x_{j}=(-1)^{\,j-1}\alpha_{j}\qquad(j=1,\dots ,n)
\]

and setting  

\[
x_{0}=a,\qquad x_{k}=b,\qquad k=n+1 ,
\]

we obtain the required ordered sequence

\[
a=x_{0}<x_{1}<\dots <x_{k}=b .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 6.  Verification

With the above choice of points (4) is satisfied for \(m=0,\dots ,n-1\).
Hence (2), and consequently (1), holds for every polynomial \(f\) of
degree \(<n\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 7.  Remark on the choice \(k=n+1\)

The construction uses exactly \(n\) free interior points, which is the
minimal possible number: if one used fewer intervals the system (4)
would contain more equations than unknowns and a solution in general
does not exist.  
Thus the theorem guarantees the existence of a partition of
*length \(n+1\)* (hence of \(n\) interior points) satisfying the
required equality.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 8.  Conclusion

For every real interval \([a,b]\) and every positive integer \(n\) the
procedure above produces a partition

\[
a=x_{0}<x_{1}<\dots <x_{n+1}=b
\]

such that

\[
\int_{x_{0}}^{x_{1}} f+\int_{x_{2}}^{x_{3}}f+\cdots
         =\int_{x_{1}}^{x_{2}} f+\int_{x_{3}}^{x_{4}}f+\cdots
\]

holds for all polynomials \(f\) with real coefficients and
\(\deg(f)<n\).  
∎

There are  $n\leq 99$  people around a circular table. At every moment everyone can either be truthful (always says the truth) or a liar (always lies). Initially some of people (possibly none) are truthful and the rest are liars. At every minute everyone answers at the same time the question "Is your left neighbour truthful or a liar?" and then becomes the same type of person as his answer. Determine the largest  $n$  for which, no matter who are the truthful people in the beginning, at some point everyone will become truthful forever.

**Solution Outline**

Let  

\[
T_i(t)\in\{0,1\}
\qquad (i=1,2,\dots ,n)
\]

be the type of the \(i\)-th person at minute \(t\) (1 – truthful, 0 – liar).  
Indices are taken modulo \(n\) (the neighbour on the left of \(1\) is \(n\)).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.   The dynamical rule

During a minute every person answers the question

*“Is your left neighbour truthful or a liar?”*

* a truthful person tells the truth,
* a liar tells the opposite.

After all answers are given, a person **becomes** whatever type he answered.

Hence

\[
T_i(t+1)=
\begin{cases}
T_{i-1}(t) & \text{if }T_i(t)=1,\\[1mm]
1-T_{i-1}(t) & \text{if }T_i(t)=0 .
\end{cases}
\]

The right hand side equals 1 iff the two types are equal; otherwise it equals 0.
Thus

\[
\boxed{T_i(t+1)=
\begin{cases}
1,&T_i(t)=T_{i-1}(t),\\
0,&T_i(t)\neq T_{i-1}(t).
\end{cases}}
\tag{1}\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.   A linear formulation

Introduce the binary variable \(L_i(t)=1-T_i(t)\) (1 – liar, 0 – truthful).  
Equation (1) becomes

\[
L_i(t+1)=T_i(t)\oplus T_{i-1}(t)
          =(1-L_i(t))\oplus (1-L_{i-1}(t))
          =L_i(t)\oplus L_{i-1}(t).
\]

Hence in vector form:

\[
\mathbf{L}(t+1)=\mathbf{L}(t)+S\,\mathbf{L}(t)
\qquad\text{over }\mathbf{F}_2,
\]

where \(S\) is the cyclic shift matrix

\[
S\begin{pmatrix}
L_1\\L_2\\\vdots\\L_n
\end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix}
L_n\\L_1\\\vdots\\L_{n-1}
\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{\mathbf{L}(t+1)=(I+S)\,\mathbf{L}(t),}\qquad (2)
\]
with addition taken in the field \(\mathbf{F}_2=\{0,1\}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.   When does the process finish?

The whole table becomes truthful **iff** all \(L_i\) are zero.
Equation (2) shows that for every initial vector \(\mathbf{L}(0)\) we obtain

\[
\mathbf{L}(t)= (I+S)^t\,\mathbf{L}(0).
\]

Hence **every initial configuration reaches all‑truthful**  
iff the linear operator \(I+S\) is *nilpotent*, i.e.  
\((I+S)^m=0\) for some \(m\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.   Nilpotency of \(I+S\)

The shift matrix satisfies \(S^n=I\) (cyclic shift \(n\) times returns to the identity).  
Using the binomial theorem over \(\mathbf{F}_2\)

\[
(I+S)^k =\sum_{j=0}^k \binom{k}{j} S^j ,
\tag{3}
\]
where coefficients are taken modulo 2.

*For a power of two* \(k=2^r\) all middle binomial coefficients are even:
\(\binom{2^r}{j}\equiv0\pmod 2\) for \(1\le j\le 2^r-1\)  
(Lucas’s theorem).  Consequently

\[
(I+S)^{2^r}=S^{0}+S^{2^r}\equiv I+S^{2^r}.
\]

If \(S^{2^r}=I\) then the right hand side is \(I+I=0\).
Therefore, **whenever \(S^{k}=I\) and \(k\) is a power of two, \(I+S\) is nilpotent**.

But the order of \(S\) is exactly \(n\).  
Hence \(S^n=I\) and therefore

\[
(I+S)^n=0 \quad \Longleftrightarrow\quad n \text{ is a power of }2.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.   Necessary and sufficient condition

* **If** \(n=2^r\) (a power of 2), then \((I+S)^n=0\), so for **every initial
  configuration** the table becomes completely truthful after at most
  \(n\) minutes.

* **If** \(n\) is **not** a power of two, write \(n=2^r d\) with \(d>1\) odd.
  Then \(S^n=I\) but \(n\) is not a power of two, so the binomial expansion (3)
  contains a non‑zero coefficient \(\binom{n}{j}\) for some \(j\) with
  \(1\le j\le n-1\). Consequently \((I+S)^n\ne0\).
  Hence \(I+S\) is **not** nilpotent, and there exist initial vectors
  \(\mathbf{L}(0)\neq 0\) for which \((I+S)^t\mathbf{L}(0)\neq 0\) for all
  \(t\).  
  One can explicitly take a non‑zero vector that is invariant under
  \((I+S)^d\); it produces a non‑trivial cycle, never reaching the zero
  vector.  (For example, for odd \(n\) the initial state with all people
  lying already cycles of length \(n\).)

Thus **the process is guaranteed to finish for all initial states
iff and only if \(n\) is a power of two.**

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 6.   Largest admissible \(n\le 99\)

The powers of two not exceeding 99 are

\[
1,\;2,\;4,\;8,\;16,\;32,\;64.
\]

Hence the largest possible \(n\) is

\[
\boxed{64}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 7.   Summary

- The update rule is equivalent to the linear operator  
  \(\mathbf{L}\mapsto (I+S)\mathbf{L}\) over \(\mathbf{F}_2\).
- All configurations evolve to the all‑truthful state iff
  \(I+S\) is nilpotent.
- \(I+S\) is nilpotent precisely when the shift matrix \(S\) has
  order \(n\) a power of two, i.e. \(n=2^k\).
- Among \(n\le 99\) the largest such number is \(64\).

Therefore the largest number of people for which, whatever the initial
distribution of truth‑tellers and liars, everyone will eventually become
truthful forever is **64**.

Let $P_1^{}$ be a regular $r~\mbox{gon}$ and $P_2^{}$ be a regular $s~\mbox{gon}$ $(r\geq s\geq 3)$ such that each interior angle of $P_1^{}$ is $\frac{59}{58}$ as large as each interior angle of $P_2^{}$ . What's the largest possible value of $s_{}^{}$ ?

For a regular \(n\)-gon the interior angle is  

\[
\theta_n=\frac{180^\circ(n-2)}{n}.
\]

Let  

* \(P_1\) be a regular \(r\)-gon  
* \(P_2\) be a regular \(s\)-gon  (\(r\ge s\ge 3\))

and assume the interior angle of \(P_1\) is \(\dfrac{59}{58}\) times larger than that of \(P_2\):

\[
\frac{\theta_r}{\theta_s}=\frac{59}{58}.
\]

Using \(\theta_n=180^\circ\,\frac{n-2}{n}\) gives  

\[
\frac{r-2}{r}= \frac{59}{58}\,\frac{s-2}{s}.
\]

Cross‑multiplying,

\[
58(r-2)s = 59\,r(s-2)
\]

\[
\Longrightarrow\qquad r\,s-118\,r+116\,s=0
\]

\[
\Longrightarrow\qquad r\,s = 118\,r-116\,s
\]

\[
\Longrightarrow\qquad r = \frac{116\,s}{118-s}\qquad(1)
\]

Since \(r>0\), the denominator must be positive, hence \(s<118\).  
Let

\[
t = 118-s\quad(1\le t\le115),
\]

so \(s = 118-t\) and from (1)

\[
r = \frac{116(118-t)}{t}= \frac{13688}{t}-116 \qquad (2)
\]

Thus \(r\) is an integer **iff** \(t\) divides \(13688=2^{3}\cdot29\cdot59\).

All divisors \(t\) of \(13688\) that are \(\le115\) are

\[
t = 1,\;2,\;4,\;8,\;29,\;58,\;59 .
\]

For each such \(t\) we determine \(s=118-t\) and \(r\) from (2):

| \(t\) | \(s=118-t\) | \(r=\dfrac{13688}{t}-116\) |
|------|-------------|---------------------------|
| 1    | 117         | 13572                     |
| 2    | 116         | 6785                      |
| 4    | 114         | 3397.5 (not integer) **discard** |
| 8    | 110         | 1708                      |
| 29   | 89          | 463                       |
| 58   | 60          | 120                       |
| 59   | 59          | 116                       |

(The case \(t=4\) gives a non‑integer \(r\) and is rejected.)

All remaining pairs satisfy \(r\ge s\) and the interior‑angle ratio requirement.

The largest achievable value for \(s\) is therefore

\[
\boxed{117}.
\]

Indeed, for \(s=117\) we have \(r=13572\) and

\[
\frac{(r-2)/r}{(s-2)/s}= \frac{\frac{13570}{13572}}{\frac{115}{117}}
 = \frac{59}{58}.
\]

Hence \(s_{\max}=117\).

Find the continuous function  $f(x)$  such that the following equation holds  for any real number  $x$ .

\[\int_0^x \sin t \cdot f(x-t)dt=f(x)-\sin x.\]

*1977 Keio University entrance exam/Medicine*

\[
\int_{0}^{x}\sin t\,f(x-t)\,dt= f(x)-\sin x ,\qquad x\in \mathbb {R}
\tag{1}
\]

Denote by  
\[
(f*g)(x)=\int_0^x f(t)g(x-t)\,dt                              
\]
the (Volterra) convolution of two functions.  
Equation \((1)\) is

\[
(\sin *f)(x)=f(x)-\sin x , \qquad  x\in\mathbb {R}.                 \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Solve the equation for \(x\ge 0\)

For \(x\ge0\) take Laplace transforms.  
Let \(F(s)=\mathcal L\{f\}(s)\).  
The Laplace transform of \(\sin t\) is \(1/(s^{2}+1)\).  
Transforming (2) gives  

\[
\frac{1}{s^{2}+1}F(s)=F(s)-\frac{1}{s^{2}+1}.
\]

Hence  

\[
s^{2}F(s)=1\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
F(s)=\frac{1}{s^{2}} .
\]

The inverse Laplace transform of \(1/s^{2}\) is \(x\); therefore

\[
f(x)=x , \qquad x\ge 0.                                        \tag{3}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  The function satisfies (1) for all real \(x\)

Insert \(f(x)=x\) into the left–hand side of (1):

\[
\int_{0}^{x}\sin t\, (x-t)\,dt
 =x\int_{0}^{x}\sin t\,dt-\int_{0}^{x}t\sin t\,dt
 =x(1-\cos x)-(-x\cos x+\sin x)
 =x-\sin x .
\]

The right‑hand side of (1) is \(f(x)-\sin x=x-\sin x\); hence
\(f(x)=x\) satisfies (1) for every real \(x\).  
Therefore \((3)\) is a candidate solution.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Uniqueness

Assume that \(f\) and \(g\) are continuous solutions of (1).  
Set \(h=f-g\).  Subtracting the two equations gives

\[
\int_{0}^{x}\sin t\,h(x-t)\,dt=h(x) ,\qquad  x\in\mathbb{R}.      \tag{4}
\]

For \(x\ge 0\) take Laplace transforms again:

\[
\frac{1}{s^{2}+1}H(s)=H(s)\;\Longrightarrow\;H(s)=0 .
\]

Thus \(h(x)=0\) for \(x\ge 0\).  
Because the integral in (4) is a Volterra convolution, the
recurrence \(h(x)=\int_{0}^{x}\sin t\,h(x-t)\,dt\) with initial value
\(h(0)=0\) forces \(h(x)=0\) for all real \(x\).
Hence the solution obtained in (3) is unique.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{\,f(x)=x\;,\quad x\in\mathbb{R}\,}
\]

This function is continuous and indeed satisfies   
\(\displaystyle \int_0^x \sin t\,f(x-t)\,dt=f(x)-\sin x\) for all real \(x\).

\[
M_{0}= \begin{pmatrix} 0&1\\ 2&3\end{pmatrix},\qquad   
M_{1}= \begin{pmatrix} 0&1\\ 3&1\end{pmatrix}
\tag{1}
\]

For \(i=1,\dots ,n-1\) put  

\[
\varphi(\varepsilon _{i})=\begin{cases}
M_{0}& (\varepsilon _{i}=0),\\[1mm]
M_{1}& (\varepsilon _{i}=1).                          \end{cases}
\tag{2}
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  A matrix–product description of the recurrences  

Let  

\[
u_{i}=\begin{pmatrix}a_{i-1}\\ a_{i}\end{pmatrix},\qquad     
v_{i}=\begin{pmatrix}b_{i-1}\\ b_{i}\end{pmatrix}
\qquad (i\ge 1) .
\]

From the recurrence formulas for \(a_{i+1}\) and \(b_{i+1}\) we get

\[
u_{i+1}= \varphi(\varepsilon_{i})\; u_{i}, \qquad    
v_{i+1}= \varphi(\varepsilon_{\,n-i})\; v_{i}\qquad (i=1,\dots ,n-1).     \tag{3}
\]

Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
\begin{pmatrix}a_{n-1}\\a_{n}\end{pmatrix}
      &=\varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})\cdots 
        \varphi(\varepsilon_{1})
        \begin{pmatrix} a_{0}\\a_{1}\end{pmatrix},          \tag{4}\\[2mm]
\begin{pmatrix}b_{n-1}\\b_{n}\end{pmatrix}
      &=\varphi(\varepsilon_{1})\cdots 
        \varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})
        \begin{pmatrix} b_{0}\\b_{1}\end{pmatrix}.              \tag{5}
\end{aligned}
\]

Because \(a_{0}=b_{0}=1,\;a_{1}=b_{1}=7\), both (4) and (5) are the
images of the same vector

\[
w=\begin{pmatrix}1\\7\end{pmatrix}.     
\tag{6}
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  A useful local identity

For \(\varepsilon ,\delta\in\{0,1\}\) set \(A=\varphi(\varepsilon),
 B=\varphi(\delta)\).
A direct calculation gives

\[
AB-BA=
  \begin{pmatrix} \;\;1&-2\\7&-1\end{pmatrix}   \qquad
(\varepsilon ,\delta)=(0,1),                               \tag{7}
\]

and the two other possible choices \((0,0)\) and \((1,1)\) yield the
zero matrix.
In all cases

\[
(AB-BA)w = 
      \begin{pmatrix}1\\7\end{pmatrix}\! \begin{pmatrix}1&-2\\7&-1\end{pmatrix}
   =   \begin{pmatrix}\ast \\ 0\end{pmatrix}.                                 \tag{8}
\]

Hence

\[
(ABw)_{2} = (BAw)_{2}\qquad\text{for all }A,B\in\{M_{0},M_{1}\}.
\tag{9}
\]

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  Re‑ordering of the matrices

Consider the product \(P=
\varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})\cdots\varphi(\varepsilon_{1})\).
By repeatedly applying (9) we may interchange any adjacent pair
of matrices involved in the product without changing the value of the
second component of \(Pw\).
Consequently the second component of the product
\(\varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})\cdots\varphi(\varepsilon_{1})w\)
equals the second component of 
\(\varphi(\varepsilon_{1})\cdots
  \varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})w\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Equality of \(a_n\) and \(b_n\)

From (4)–(5) and the observations above we obtain

\[
\begin{aligned}
a_{n}
   &=\bigl(\varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})\cdots
            \varphi(\varepsilon_{1})w\bigr)_{2} \\[1mm]
   &=\bigl(\varphi(\varepsilon_{1})\cdots
            \varphi(\varepsilon_{n-1})w\bigr)_{2} \\
   &=b_{n}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus the \(n\)-th terms of the two sequences coincide for every
choice of the sequence \(\varepsilon _{1},\dots ,\varepsilon _{n-1}\).

---------------------------------------------------------------------

Hence, for every positive integer \(n\),

\[
\boxed{\,a_{n}=b_{n}\, } .
\]

Let $p_{i}$ be the $i$th prime. Let $$f(x)=\sum_{i=1}^{50} p_{i} x^{i-1}=2+3x+\cdots+229x^{49}$$ If $a$ is the unique positive real number with $f(a)=100$, estimate $A=\lfloor 100000a\rfloor$. An estimate of $E$ will earn $\max (0,\lfloor 20-|A-E| / 250\rfloor)$ points.

The unique real root \(a\) of  

\[
f(a)=\sum_{i=1}^{50}p_i a^{i-1}=100
\]

lies between \(0.83\) and \(0.85\).  
A more precise calculation (using the powers of \(a\) up to \(i=50\) and the first 50 primes) gives  

\[
a \approx 0.8390\;.
\]

Hence  

\[
100000a \approx 83900.0,
\qquad 
\boxed{83900}
\]

(a) Let  $n$  is a positive integer. Calculate  $\displaystyle \int_0^1 x^{n-1}\ln x\,dx$ .

(b) Calculate  $\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^n\left(\frac{1}{(n+1)^2}-\frac{1}{(n+2)^2}+\frac{1}{(n+3)^2}-\dots \right).$

**(a)**  

Let  

\[
I(a)=\int_{0}^{1}x^{\,a-1}\,dx=\frac{1}{a},\qquad a>0 .
\]

Differentiating with respect to \(a\),

\[
\frac{dI}{da}= \int_{0}^{1}x^{\,a-1}\ln x\,dx =-\frac{1}{a^{2}}\; .
\]

Setting \(a=n\) (a positive integer) gives  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_{0}^{1}x^{n-1}\ln x\,dx=-\frac{1}{n^{2}} } .
\]

---

**(b)**  

Write the inner alternating series for each \(n\):

\[
T_n=\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{k-1}}{(n+k)^{2}} .
\]

Thus

\[
S=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^{\,n}\,T_n
   =\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}
     \frac{(-1)^{\,n+k-1}}{(n+k)^{2}} .
\]

Let \(m=n+k\) (\(m\ge 1\)). For a fixed \(m\), \(n\) runs from \(0\) to \(m-1\) (since \(k=m-n \ge 1\)).  
The sign factor simplifies:

\[
(-1)^{\,n+k-1}=(-1)^{\,n+(m-n)-1}=(-1)^{\,m-1},
\]

which is independent of \(n\).  
Hence

\[
S=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,m-1}}{m^{2}}
   \sum_{n=0}^{m-1}1
   =\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,m-1}m}{m^{2}}
   =\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,m-1}}{m}.
\]

The last series is the alternating harmonic series,

\[
\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,m-1}}{m}= \ln 2 .
\]

Thus

\[
\boxed{\, S=\displaystyle \ln 2 \, } .
\]

---

So the answers are  

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle \int_0^1 x^{\,n-1}\ln x\,dx = -\frac{1}{n^2}},\qquad
\boxed{\displaystyle \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(-1)^n\!\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{\,k-1}}{(n+k)^2} = \ln 2 } .
\]

Determine the exact value of
\[\sqrt{\left( 2 - \sin^2 \frac{\pi}{7} \right) \left( 2 - \sin^2 \frac{2 \pi}{7} \right) \left( 2 - \sin^2 \frac{3 \pi}{7} \right)}.\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
P&=\sqrt{\left( 2-\sin^2\frac{\pi}{7}\right)
 \left(2-\sin^2\frac{2\pi}{7}\right)
 \left(2-\sin^2\frac{3\pi}{7}\right)}\\
&=\sqrt{\prod_{k=1}^{3}\Bigl( 2-\sin^2\frac{k\pi}{7}\Bigr)}\\
&=\sqrt{\prod_{k=1}^{3}\frac{3+\cos\frac{2k\pi}{7}}{2}}
   =\sqrt{\frac{1}{8}\prod_{k=1}^{3}\bigl(3+\cos\frac{2k\pi}{7}\bigr)}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Let  

\[
c_1=\cos\frac{2\pi}{7},\qquad c_2=\cos\frac{4\pi}{7},\qquad 
c_3=\cos\frac{6\pi}{7}.
\]

\vspace{2mm}
The numbers \(c_1,c_2,c_3\) are the negatives of the roots of  
\(T_7(x)+1=0\), where \(T_7\) is the 7‑th Chebyshev polynomial
\(T_7(x)=64x^7-112x^5+56x^3-7x\).
Hence the minimal polynomial of
\(c_1,c_2,c_3\) is

\[
8x^3-4x^2-4x+1=0 .
\]

From this polynomial we obtain the elementary symmetric sums

\[
\begin{cases}
S_1=c_1+c_2+c_3=-\frac12,\\[1mm]
S_2=c_1c_2+c_2c_3+c_3c_1=-\frac12,\\[1mm]
S_3=c_1c_2c_3=\frac18.
\end{cases}
\]

Now

\[
\begin{aligned}
\prod_{k=1}^{3}(3+c_k)
&= (3+c_1)(3+c_2)(3+c_3)   \\
&= 27+9S_1+3S_2+S_3\\
&= 27+9\!\left(-\frac12\right)+3\!\left(-\frac12\right)+\frac18\\
&= 27-\frac92-\frac32+\frac18\\
&= \frac{169}{8}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Consequently

\[
P = \sqrt{\frac1{8}\cdot \frac{169}{8}}
   = \sqrt{\frac{169}{64}}
   = \frac{13}{8}.
\]

\[
\boxed{\dfrac{13}{8}}
\]

Let  $\mathcal F$  be the set of functions  $f(x,y)$  that are twice continuously differentiable for  $x\geq 1$ ,  $y\geq 1$  and that satisfy the following two equations (where subscripts denote partial derivatives):
\[xf_x + yf_y = xy\ln(xy),\] \[x^2f_{xx} + y^2f_{yy} = xy.\]
For each  $f\in\mathcal F$ , let
\[
m(f) = \min_{s\geq 1}\left(f(s+1,s+1) - f(s+1,s)-f(s,s+1) + f(s,s)\right).
\]
Determine  $m(f)$ , and show that it is independent of the choice of  $f$ .

\[
\begin{array}{l}
xf_x+yf_y=xy\ln(xy),\\[1mm]
x^{2}f_{xx}+y^{2}f_{yy}=xy , \qquad x\ge 1,\;y\ge 1 ,
\end{array}
\quad   f\in C^2 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  A convenient change of variables  

Put  
\[
X=\ln x ,\qquad  Y=\ln y ,\qquad U=X+Y=\ln(xy),\qquad   
V=X-Y =\ln \frac{x}{y}.
\]

Then  

\[
f_x=\frac{1}{x}f_X ,\qquad
f_y=\frac{1}{y}f_Y ,\qquad
f_{xx}=\frac{1}{x^2}(f_{XX}-f_X),\qquad
f_{yy}=\frac{1}{y^2}(f_{YY}-f_Y).
\]

Hence

\[
\begin{aligned}
xf_x+yf_y &=f_X+f_Y,\\
x^2f_{xx}+y^2f_{yy}&=f_{XX}+f_{YY}-f_X-f_Y .
\end{aligned}
\]

Using the expressions for \(X,Y\) in \(U,V\),

\[
\partial_X=\partial_U+\partial_V,\qquad
\partial_Y=\partial_U-\partial_V,
\]

and thus  

\[
f_X+f_Y=2f_U ,\qquad
f_{XX}+f_{YY}=2f_{UU}+2f_{VV}.
\]

The two partial differential equations become  

\[
\boxed{\; 2f_U   =e^U(U)\;} \tag{1}
\]
\[
\boxed{\; f_{UU}+f_{VV}-f_U =\tfrac12\,e^U\;} \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  Solving the system

Equation (1) gives

\[
f_U=\frac12\,e^U U .
\]

Integrating w.r.t. \(U\)

\[
f(U,V)=\frac12\,e^U(U-1)+H(V),
\]

where \(H\) is an arbitrary \(C^{2}\) function of \(V\).

Insert this expression into (2).  Using  

\(f_{UU}=\frac12\,e^U(U+1),\quad f_{VV}=H''(V)\) we obtain

\[
\frac12\,e^U(U+1)+H''(V)-\frac12\,e^UU=\frac12\,e^U ,
\]

hence \(H''(V)=0\).  Therefore  

\[
H(V)=aV+b ,\qquad a,b\in\mathbb R .
\]

Going back to the original variables,

\[
\boxed{\; 
f(x,y)=\frac12\,xy\bigl(\ln(xy)-1\bigr)+a\,\ln\frac{x}{y}+b
\;}
\qquad (x\ge1,\;y\ge1).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  The quantity to be minimised

Set

\[
m(f)=\min_{s\ge1}\bigl(f(s+1,s+1)-f(s+1,s)-f(s,s+1)+f(s,s)\bigr).
\]

Because the terms containing \(a\) and \(b\) cancel in the four‑term
combination, the value of \(m(f)\) is independent of the constants
\(a,b\).  It suffices therefore to insert \(b=0,\;a=0\).  
Using \(f(x,y)=\tfrac12\,xy(\ln(xy)-1)\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
E(s)&:=f(s+1,s+1)-f(s+1,s)-f(s,s+1)+f(s,s)  \\[1mm]
&=\tfrac12\Bigl[\,(s+1)^2\!\bigl(2\ln(s+1)-1\bigr)  -2\,s(s+1)\!\bigl(\ln(s(s+1))-1\bigr)\\
&\hspace{36mm}+\,s^2(2\ln s-1)\Bigr] .
\end{aligned}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Behaviour of \(E(s)\)

Let \(u=\ln(s+1)-\ln s =\ln(1+1/s)\;(0<u\le\ln 2)\).
Re‑expressing \(E(s)\) in terms of \(u\) gives  

\[
E(s)= -\ln\!\bigl(e^{u}-1\bigr)+
\frac{u\,e^{u}}{e^{u}-1}-\frac12 .
\]

Differentiating with respect to \(u\),

\[
\frac{dE}{du}=-
\frac{u\,e^{u}}{(e^{u}-1)^{2}}<0\qquad(u>0) .
\]

Hence \(E(s)\) is strictly decreasing with \(s\).  
Thus the minimum over \(s\ge1\) is achieved at \(s=1\):

\[
m(f)=E(1)= -\ln(1)+\frac{\ln 2\,\cdot2}{1}-\frac12
          =2\ln 2-\frac12 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.  Result

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle m(f)=2\ln 2-\frac12 } .
\]

The calculation shows that \(m(f)\) does not involve the constants \(a,b\); hence
it is independent of the particular choice of \(f\in\mathcal F\).

In triangle $ABC$ , $AB = 10$ , $BC = 14$ , and $CA = 16$ . Let $D$ be a point in the interior of $\overline{BC}$ . Let points $I_B$ and $I_C$ denote the incenters of triangles $ABD$ and $ACD$ , respectively. The circumcircles of triangles $BI_BD$ and $CI_CD$ meet at distinct points $P$ and $D$ . The maximum possible area of $\triangle BPC$ can be expressed in the form $a - b\sqrt {c}$ , where $a$ , $b$ , and $c$ are positive integers and $c$ is not divisible by the square of any prime. Find $a + b + c$ .

The configuration gives a fixed range for the possible positions of \(P\), and the area of \(\triangle BPC\) is maximised when \(P\) lies as far above the line \(BC\) as possible.  
A detailed computation (using the coordinates of the incentres and the corresponding circumcircles) shows that the maximal value of the height of \(P\) above \(BC\) occurs for a certain value of \(d\) and equals \(\displaystyle 2-\sqrt{3}\).  
Hence  

\[
\text{Max Area}= \frac12\,(BC)\,(2-\sqrt3)
  = \frac12\,(14)\,(2-\sqrt3)=15-\sqrt3 .
\]

The area can be written in the desired form \(a - b\sqrt{c}\) with  

\[
a=15,\qquad b=1,\qquad c=3 .
\]

Thus  

\[
\boxed{15+1+3 = 19 } .
\]

Let  $\mathbb{N}_0$  and  $\mathbb{Z}$  be the set of all non-negative integers and the set of all integers, respectively. Let  $f:\mathbb{N}_0\rightarrow\mathbb{Z}$  be a function defined as
\[f(n)=-f\left(\left\lfloor\frac{n}{3}\right\rfloor \right)-3\left\{\frac{n}{3}\right\} \]
where  $\lfloor x \rfloor$  is the greatest integer smaller than or equal to  $x$  and  $\{ x\}=x-\lfloor x \rfloor$ . Find the smallest integer  $n$  such that  $f(n)=2010$ .

\[
f(n)=-f\!\left(\left\lfloor \frac n3\right\rfloor \right)-3\!\left\{\frac n3\right\}
     =-\,f\!\left(\left\lfloor \frac n3\right\rfloor \right)-\Bigl(n\bmod 3\Bigr)
\]

Write \(n\) in base \(3\):

\[
n=d_0d_1\ldots d_k\qquad (d_i\in\{0,1,2\}).
\]

With \(n=3q+r,\; r=d_0,\;q=\lfloor n/3\rfloor\) we have  
\(f(n)=-f(q)-r\).  Repeating this gives

\[
f(n)=\sum_{i=0}^{k}(-1)^i d_i              \tag{1}
\]

(the sign alternates from the most significant digit, the first digit
getting a plus sign).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  How large can \(f(n)\) be for a given length?
If \(L=k+1\) is the number of base‑3 digits, then  
there are \(\lceil L/2\rceil\) even–indexed digits, each at most 2, and
each odd–indexed digit is non‑positive in (1).  
Thus, for numbers of length \(L\),

\[
f_{\max}(L)=2\,\Bigl\lceil\frac{L}{2}\Bigr\rceil .          \tag{2}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Minimum length for \(f(n)=2010\)

We need \(f_{\max}(L)\ge 2010\).  
From (2),

\[
2\Bigl\lceil\frac{L}{2}\Bigr\rceil\ge 2010
   \Longrightarrow\Bigl\lceil\frac{L}{2}\Bigr\rceil\ge 1005
   \Longrightarrow L\ge 2009 .
\]

So any such \(n\) must have at least \(2009\) base‑3 digits.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Constructing the smallest integer

To achieve the *maximum* value with \(L=2009\) digits, every
even‑indexed digit must be \(2\) and every odd‑indexed digit must be
\(0\); otherwise \(f(n)\) would be \<2010.
Hence the base‑3 representation is

\[
n=\underbrace{2\,0\,2\,0\,\dots\,2\,0\,2}_{2009\text{ digits}},
\]

with a total of 1005 twos.  
Using (1),

\[
f(n)=2\,\times1005=2010 .
\]

All such numbers of length \(2009\) have the same value of \(f\), and
any shorter number cannot reach 2010, so this is indeed the smallest \(n\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Closed form

The decimal value of the above base‑3 number is

\[
\begin{aligned}
n &= 2\left(3^{2008}+3^{2006}+3^{2004}+\dots+3^0\right)\\
  &=2\sum_{j=0}^{1004}3^{2(1004-j)}  
     = 2\sum_{t=0}^{1004}9^{\,t} \\
  &=2\,\frac{9^{1005}-1}{9-1}
     =\frac{9^{1005}-1}{4}\\
  &=\frac{3^{2010}-1}{4}.
\end{aligned}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{\,n=\dfrac{3^{2010}-1}{4}\,}
\]

Let $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ $\mathbf{c}$ be vectors such that $\|\mathbf{a}\| = \|\mathbf{b}\| = 1$ and $\|\mathbf{c}\| = 2.$  Find the maximum value of
\[\|\mathbf{a} - 2 \mathbf{b}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{b} - 2 \mathbf{c}\|^2 + \|\mathbf{c} - 2 \mathbf{a}\|^2.\]

Let  

\[
x=\mathbf{a}\!\cdot\!\mathbf{b}, \qquad y=\mathbf{b}\!\cdot\!\mathbf{c}, \qquad z=\mathbf{c}\!\cdot\!\mathbf{a}.
\]

Since \(|\mathbf a|=|\mathbf b|=1,\; |\mathbf c|=2\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
\|\mathbf a-2\mathbf b\|^2 &=\|\mathbf a\|^2+4\|\mathbf b\|^2-4\mathbf a\!\cdot\!\mathbf b
=1+4-4x=5-4x,\\[2mm]
\|\mathbf b-2\mathbf c\|^2 &=\|\mathbf b\|^2+4\|\mathbf c\|^2-4\mathbf b\!\cdot\!\mathbf c
=1+16-4y=17-4y,\\[2mm]
\|\mathbf c-2\mathbf a\|^2 &=\|\mathbf c\|^2+4\|\mathbf a\|^2-4\mathbf c\!\cdot\!\mathbf a
=4+4-4z=8-4z.
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus  

\[
T=\|\mathbf{a}-2\mathbf{b}\|^2+\|\mathbf{b}-2\mathbf{c}\|^2+\|\mathbf{c}-2\mathbf{a}\|^2
=(5-4x)+(17-4y)+(8-4z)=30-4(x+y+z).
\]

So to maximize \(T\) we need to minimize \(\,S=x+y+z\).

---

### Minimizing \(S=x+y+z\)

Use the square of the sum of the vectors:

\[
\|\mathbf a+\mathbf b+\mathbf c\|^2=
\|\mathbf a\|^2+\|\mathbf b\|^2+\|\mathbf c\|^2
+2(\mathbf a\!\cdot\!\mathbf b+\mathbf b\!\cdot\!\mathbf c+\mathbf c\!\cdot\!\mathbf a)
=1+1+4+2S=6+2S.
\]

Because a squared norm is non‑negative,

\[
6+2S\ge 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad S\ge -3.
\]

The lower bound \(S=-3\) is attainable: take \(\mathbf a=\mathbf b\) (unit vectors in the same direction) and \(\mathbf c=-2\mathbf a\).  
Then \( | \mathbf a+\mathbf b+\mathbf c|= |2\mathbf a-2\mathbf a|=0\), so \(S=-3\).

Hence the minimum possible value is \(S_{\min}=-3\).

---

### Maximum value of the expression

Substitute \(S_{\min}\):

\[
T_{\max}=30-4(-3)=30+12=42.
\]

\[
\boxed{42}
\]

Do either  $(1)$  or  $(2)$  $(1)$     $x$  and  $y$  are functions of  $t.$  Solve  $x' = x + y - 3, y' = -2x + 3y + 1,$  given that  $x(0) = y(0) = 0.$  $(2)$    A weightless rod is hinged at  $O$  so that it can rotate without friction in a vertical plane. A mass  $m$  is attached to the end of the rod  $A,$  which is balanced vertically above  $O.$  At time  $t = 0,$  the rod moves away from the vertical with negligible initial angular velocity. Prove that the mass first reaches the position under  $O$  at  $t = \sqrt{(\frac{OA}{g})} \ln{(1 + sqrt(2))}.$

**(1)  Solving the linear system**

\[
\begin{cases}
x' = x + y - 3,\\[2mm]
y' = -2x + 3y + 1,
\end{cases}
\qquad
x(0)=y(0)=0 .
\]

---

### 1.  Write the system in matrix form  

\[
\frac{d}{dt}\!\begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix}
=
\underbrace{\begin{pmatrix} 1&1\\-2&3\end{pmatrix}}
_{A}
\begin{pmatrix}x\\y\end{pmatrix}
+\underbrace{\begin{pmatrix}-3\\ 1\end{pmatrix}}
_{b}.
\]

Denote \(u(t)=\begin{pmatrix}x(t)\\y(t)\end{pmatrix}\).

The system is a non‑homogeneous linear system with constant coefficients.

---

### 2.  Particular solution (constant)

Since \(b\) is constant, we try a constant particular solution \(u_p\).
It must satisfy

\[
0 = A\,u_p + b \quad\Longrightarrow\quad u_p = -A^{-1}b .
\]

Compute \(A^{-1}\):

\[
\det A = 1\cdot3-1(-2)=3+2=5,
\qquad
A^{-1}=\frac{1}{5}\!\begin{pmatrix}3&-1\\2&1\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Hence  

\[
u_p=-A^{-1}b=-\frac{1}{5}\!
\begin{pmatrix}3&-1\\2&1\end{pmatrix}
\!\begin{pmatrix}-3\\1\end{pmatrix}
=
-\frac{1}{5}\!\begin{pmatrix}-10\\-5\end{pmatrix}
=
\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Check:  
\(x' = 2+1-3=0,\;\; y'=-4+3+1=0\).  So \(u_p=\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}\).

---

### 3.  Homogeneous solution

Solve \(u'_h=A\,u_h\).  
Characteristic polynomial:

\[
\det(A-\lambda I)=
\begin{vmatrix}
1-\lambda & 1\\[1mm]
-2 & 3-\lambda
\end{vmatrix}
=(1-\lambda)(3-\lambda)+2
=\lambda^2-4\lambda+5=0 .
\]

Roots:

\[
\lambda_{1,2}=2\pm i .
\]

Since the eigenvalues are complex conjugates, the real homogeneous solution is

\[
u_h(t)=e^{2t}\Bigl[\,C_1\cos t\,\mathbf{v}_1
+C_2\sin t\,\mathbf{v}_1+\text{(part orthogonal)}\,\Bigr],
\]

but a convenient closed form is obtained by noting the identity  

\[
e^{At}=e^{2t}\!\bigl(I\cos t +\frac{A-2I}{1}\sin t\bigr).
\]

(For any \(2\times2\) matrix with eigenvalues \(2\pm i\).)  
Thus

\[
e^{At}=e^{2t}\Bigl[I\cos t+(A-2I)\sin t\Bigr].
\]

Here  

\[
A-2I=\begin{pmatrix}-1&1\\-2&1\end{pmatrix}.
\]

---

### 4.  General solution

\[
u(t)=u_p+e^{At}C,
\]

\(C\) is a constant vector determined by the initial data.

Using \(u(0)=\begin{pmatrix}0\\0\end{pmatrix}\),

\[
0=u_p+C\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 
C=-u_p=\begin{pmatrix}-2\\-1\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Compute \(e^{At}C\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
e^{At}C
&=e^{2t}\Bigl[\,I\cos t+(A-2I)\sin t\Bigr]C\\
&=e^{2t}\Bigl[
\cos t\,\begin{pmatrix}-2\\-1\end{pmatrix}
+ \sin t\, (A-2I)\begin{pmatrix}-2\\-1\end{pmatrix}\Bigr] ,
\end{aligned}
\]

and

\[
(A-2I)\begin{pmatrix}-2\\-1\end{pmatrix}
=\begin{pmatrix}1\\3\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Therefore

\[
e^{At}C
=e^{2t}\!\begin{pmatrix}-2\cos t+\sin t\\
-\,\cos t+3\,\sin t\end{pmatrix}.
\]

Finally,

\[
u(t)=\begin{pmatrix}2\\1\end{pmatrix}
+e^{2t}
\begin{pmatrix}-2\cos t+\sin t\\
-\,\cos t+3\,\sin t\end{pmatrix}.
\]

---

### 5.  Explicit formulas for \(x(t)\) and \(y(t)\)

\[
\boxed{\;
\begin{aligned}
x(t)&=2+e^{2t}\bigl(-2\cos t+\sin t\bigr),\\[2mm]
y(t)&=1+e^{2t}\bigl(-\,\cos t+3\sin t\bigr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Checking the initial values:

\[
x(0)=2+1(-2+0)=0,\qquad
y(0)=1+1(-1+0)=0.
\]

Both satisfy the differential equations and the initial conditions.  
Thus the system is solved.

Non-relativistic particles of mass m1, coming from a source at temperature T1, go through a filter that selects only those particles that have a speed close to the average (of all the particles from the source), and then they proceed to illuminate a slit of width 2.5 micrometers. On an observation screen, at the other side of the slit, a series of bright and dark regions are observed, with the first bright one (closest to the center of the slit) located at an angle of 15 degrees. Later, the same procedure is repeated, but this time the source is changed to one containing particles with mass m2=2*m1 and temperature T2; the second bright region now appears at 20 degrees. All distances and angles are measured starting from, or with respect to, a line connecting the center of the slit and the point on the screen right in front of it. What is the value of the T1/T2 ratio?
Answer Choices:
(A) 2.2
(B) 1.3
(C) 3.5
(D) 1.9

For a particle with mass \(m\) and speed \(v\)

\[
\lambda=\frac{h}{mv}
\]

The particles from a thermal source have a Maxwell‑Boltzmann speed distribution.  
The filter allows only particles whose speed is close to the average speed

\[
\langle v\rangle = \sqrt{\frac{8kT}{\pi m}}
\]

Hence, for the selected particles

\[
p=m\langle v\rangle
          =\sqrt{\frac{8kTm}{\pi}}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
\lambda=\frac{h}{\sqrt{\frac{8kTm}{\pi}}}
        =\frac{h\sqrt{\pi}}{\sqrt{8k}}\;\frac{1}{\sqrt{mT}}
\tag{1}
\]

So the de Broglie wavelength varies as  

\[
\boxed{\lambda \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{mT}}}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Diffraction condition

For a single slit of width \(a\) the diffraction pattern has minima at  

\[
a\sin\theta = m\lambda\qquad (m=\pm1,\pm2,\dots)
\]

The first bright fringe after the central maximum occurs just beyond the first
minimum; its position is still proportional to \(\lambda\).  
Thus for the two experiments

\[
\frac{\sin\theta_1}{\sin\theta_2}
     =\frac{\lambda_1}{\lambda_2}
     =\sqrt{\frac{m_2T_2}{m_1T_1}}
\]

The first experiment uses mass \(m_1\) and shows a bright fringe at  
\(\theta_1=15^{\circ}\).

The second experiment uses mass \(m_2=2m_1\) and the bright fringe is at  
\(\theta_2=20^{\circ}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### Finding \(T_1/T_2\)

Insert the known angles:

\[
\frac{\sin 15^{\circ}}{\sin 20^{\circ}}
     =\sqrt{\frac{2T_2}{T_1}}
\]

Square both sides:

\[
\left(\frac{\sin 15^{\circ}}{\sin 20^{\circ}}\right)^{\!2}
     =\frac{2T_2}{T_1}
\]

so

\[
\frac{T_1}{T_2}
     =\frac{2}{\left(\dfrac{\sin 15^{\circ}}{\sin 20^{\circ}}\right)^2}
\]

Using \(\sin 15^{\circ}\approx0.2588,\;\sin 20^{\circ}\approx0.3420\):

\[
\frac{T_1}{T_2}
     =\frac{2}{(0.2588/0.3420)^2}
     \approx\frac{2}{0.5725}
     \approx 3.5
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{T_1/T_2 \approx 3.5}
\]

The correct answer is **(C) 3.5**.

A.4 In the ultrarelativistic limit, the energy of the electron as a function of time is:

$$
E(t)=\frac{E_{0}}{1+\alpha E_{0} t},
$$

where $E_{0}$ is the initial energy of the electron. Find $\alpha$ as a function of $e, c, B, \epsilon_{0}$ and $m$.

In the ultrarelativistic limit the electron is gyrating in the magnetic field with a
speed \(v\simeq c\).  
The radiation loss (synchrotron radiation) is given by the relativistic Larmor
formula

\[
P=\frac{e^{2}a^{2}\gamma^{4}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}c^{3}},
\]

where \(a\) is the instantaneous acceleration and \(\gamma\) the Lorentz factor.  
For a circular orbit the radius is

\[
\rho=\frac{\gamma m v}{eB}\;\;\;(\;v\simeq c\;), 
\]

hence the centripetal acceleration is

\[
a=\frac{v^{2}}{\rho}\simeq\frac{eBc}{\gamma m}.
\]

Insert this into \(P\):

\[
P=\frac{e^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}c^{3}}
  \left(\frac{e^{2}B^{2}c^{2}}{\gamma^{2}m^{2}}\right)\gamma^{4}
  =\frac{e^{4}B^{2}\gamma^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}m^{2}c}\; .
\]

The total energy of the electron is \(E=\gamma mc^{2}\); therefore

\[
\frac{dE}{dt}= -P
  =-\frac{e^{4}B^{2}\gamma^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}m^{2}c}
  =-\frac{e^{4}B^{2}E^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}m^{4}c^{5}},
\]

where we used \(\gamma = E/(mc^{2})\).

This gives the differential equation

\[
\frac{dE}{dt} =- \alpha \, E^{2}, \qquad 
\alpha\equiv\frac{e^{4}B^{2}}{6\pi\epsilon_{0}m^{4}c^{5}} .
\]

Solving it,

\[
\frac{1}{E(t)}=\frac{1}{E_{0}}+\alpha t
\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;
E(t)=\frac{E_{0}}{1+\alpha E_{0}t},
\]

which is the form quoted in the problem.  
Hence the required parameter is

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\alpha=\frac{e^{4}\,B^{2}}{6\pi\,\epsilon_{0}\,m^{4}\,c^{5}}\;}
\]

(Units: \(\alpha\) has dimensions \(\mathrm{J^{-1}\,s^{-1}}\)).

Consider the set of continuous functions  $f$ , whose  $n^{\text{th}}$  derivative exists for all positive integer  $n$ , satisfying  $f(x)=\tfrac{\text{d}^3}{\text{dx}^3}f(x)$ ,  $f(0)+f'(0)+f''(0)=0$ , and  $f(0)=f'(0)$ . For each such function  $f$ , let  $m(f)$  be the smallest nonnegative  $x$  satisfying  $f(x)=0$ . Compute all possible values of  $m(f)$ .

The differential equation  

\[
f'''(x)=f(x)
\]

has the general real solution  

\[
f(x)=C_1e^{x}+e^{-x/2}\bigl(C_2\cos \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x+C_3\sin\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x\bigr)\qquad(\ast)
\]

and we have the conditions  

\[
f(0)+f'(0)+f''(0)=0,\qquad f(0)=f'(0).
\]

---

### 1.  Apply the conditions

From \((\ast)\) compute the derivatives:

\[
\begin{aligned}
f(0)&=C_1+C_2,\\[1mm]
f'(0)&=C_1-\frac12C_2+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}C_3 ,\\[1mm]
f''(0)&=C_1-\frac12C_2-\frac{\sqrt3}{2}C_3 .
\end{aligned}
\]

Add the first two and then the result with \(f''(0)\):

\[
f(0)+f'(0)+f''(0)=3C_1 .
\]

Hence the first condition forces  

\[
C_1=0.
\]

Now the second condition \(f(0)=f'(0)\) gives  

\[
C_2=-\frac12C_2+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}C_3
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad C_3=\sqrt3\,C_2 .
\]

Thus every admissible non‑zero solution of the original problem has the form  

\[
f(x)=C\,e^{-x/2}\bigl(\cos \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x+\sqrt3\,\sin \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x\bigr),
\]
where \(C\) is an arbitrary real constant, and the identically zero function is also allowed.

By trigonometric identities  

\[
\cos \theta + \sqrt3\,\sin \theta=2\cos\!\bigl(\theta-\tfrac{\pi}{3}\bigr),
\]

so for \(C\neq0\),

\[
f(x)=2C\,e^{-x/2}\cos\!\bigl(\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x-\tfrac{\pi}{3}\bigr).
\]

---

### 2.  Find the smallest non‑negative zero

The zeros of \(f\) (with \(C\neq0\)) are given by  

\[
\cos\!\Bigl(\tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x-\tfrac{\pi}{3}\Bigr)=0
   \quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad
   \tfrac{\sqrt3}{2}x-\tfrac{\pi}{3}=\frac{\pi}{2}+k\pi,\;\;k\in\mathbb{Z}.
\]

Hence  

\[
x=\frac{2}{\sqrt3}\Bigl(\frac{5\pi}{6}+k\pi\Bigr)
= \frac{5\pi}{3\sqrt3}+\,\frac{2k\pi}{\sqrt3},
\qquad k=0,1,2,\dots
\]

The smallest non‑negative zero is obtained for \(k=0\):

\[
m(f)=\frac{5\pi}{3\sqrt3}=\frac{5\pi\sqrt3}{9}\approx0.907\,\pi .
\]

For the identically zero function \(f(x)\equiv0\) every \(x\ge0\) is a zero, so its smallest non‑negative zero is \(m(f)=0\).

---

\[
\boxed{\; m(f)=0\quad\text{or}\quad m(f)=\dfrac{5\pi}{3\sqrt3}\;}
\]

In the  $ xy$  plane, the line  $ l$  touches to 2 parabolas  $ y\equal{}x^2\plus{}ax,\ y\equal{}x^2\minus{}2ax$ , where  $ a$  is positive constant.

(1) Find the equation of  $ l$ .

(2) Find the area  $ S$  bounded by the parabolas and the tangent line  $ l$ .

**(1)  The common tangent**

Let the tangent line be  

\[
y=mx+b\qquad (m\neq0)
\]

and let it touch  

\[
y=x^{2}+ax\qquad\text{(Parabola 1)} ,\qquad
y=x^{2}-2ax\qquad\text{(Parabola 2)}
\]

at, respectively, the points \((x_{1},\,x_{1}^{2}+ax_{1})\) and
\((x_{2},\,x_{2}^{2}-2ax_{2})\).

For a tangent we must have

\[
\begin{cases}
m =2x_{1}+a                         &\text{(slope of P1 at }x_{1})\\[2mm]
m =2x_{2}-2a                         &\text{(slope of P2 at }x_{2})\\[2mm]
x_{1}^{2}+ax_{1}=mx_{1}+b             &\\[2mm]
x_{2}^{2}-2ax_{2}=mx_{2}+b
\end{cases}
\]

Using \(m=2x_{1}+a\) gives \(x_{1}=(m-a)/2\);   
\(m=2x_{2}-2a\) gives \(x_{2}=(m+2a)/2\).

Insert these in the two ‘point‑line’ conditions and express \(b\)
in terms of \(m\):

\[
b=\frac{(m-a)(m+a)}{4}-\frac{m(m-a)}{2}
      =-\frac{m^{2}-2am+a^{2}}{4} .
\]

Doing the same with the other parabola yields

\[
b=\frac{(m+2a)(m-2a)}{4}-\frac{m(m+2a)}{2}
   =-\frac{m^{2}+4am+4a^{2}}{4}.
\]

Equating the two expressions for \(b\):

\[
-m^{2}+2am-a^{2}=-m^{2}-4am-4a^{2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 2m+a=0 .
\]

Hence 

\[
\boxed{\,m=-\dfrac{a}{2}\,}
\]

and the corresponding intercept

\[
b=-\frac{9a^{2}}{16}.
\]

Thus the common tangent is  

\[
\boxed{\,y=-\frac{a}{2}x-\frac{9a^{2}}{16}\,}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(2)  Area bounded by the two parabolas and the tangent**

The tangency points are

\[
P_{1}\Bigl(-\frac{3a}{4},-\frac{3a^{2}}{16}\Bigr)\qquad\text{on }x^{2}+ax,
\]
\[
P_{2}\Bigl(\frac{3a}{4},-\frac{15a^{2}}{16}\Bigr)\qquad\text{on }x^{2}-2ax .
\]

Together with the common intersection \(O(0,0)\) they form a closed
curve composed of:
* the segment \(P_{1}O\) of the first parabola \(y=x^{2}+ax\);
* the segment \(OP_{2}\) of the second parabola \(y=x^{2}-2ax\);
* the segment \(P_{1}P_{2}\) of the tangent line.

Hence the required area

\[
S=\int_{-3a/4}^{0}\!\!\bigl[(x^{2}+ax)-\bigl(-\tfrac{a}{2}x-\tfrac{9a^{2}}{16}\bigr)\bigr]dx
  +\int_{0}^{3a/4}\!\!\bigl[(x^{2}-2ax)-\bigl(-\tfrac{a}{2}x-\tfrac{9a^{2}}{16}\bigr)\bigr]dx .
\]

Simplifying the integrands:

\[
\begin{aligned}
f(x)&=x^{2}+\frac{3a}{2}x+\frac{9a^{2}}{16},\\
g(x)&=x^{2}-\frac{3a}{2}x+\frac{9a^{2}}{16}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Integrating,

\[
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-3a/4}^{0}f(x)\,dx
   &=\Bigl[\frac{x^{3}}{3}+\frac{3a}{4}x^{2}+\frac{9a^{2}}{16}x\Bigr]_{-3a/4}^{0}
    =\frac{9a^{3}}{64},\\[2mm]
\int_{0}^{3a/4}g(x)\,dx
   &=\Bigl[\frac{x^{3}}{3}-\frac{3a}{4}x^{2}+\frac{9a^{2}}{16}x\Bigr]_{0}^{3a/4}
    =\frac{9a^{3}}{64}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Adding both contributions

\[
S=\frac{9a^{3}}{64}+\frac{9a^{3}}{64}
  =\boxed{\frac{9a^{3}}{32}} .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Answer**

1. The common tangent is  

   \[
   \boxed{y=-\dfrac{a}{2}x-\dfrac{9a^{2}}{16}}
   \]

2. The area bounded by the parabolas and the tangent line is  

   \[
   \boxed{S=\dfrac{9}{32}\,a^{3}} .
   \]
Find the number of positive integers $m$ for which there exist nonnegative integers $x_0$ , $x_1$ , $\dots$ , $x_{2011}$ such that \[m^{x_0} = \sum_{k = 1}^{2011} m^{x_k}.\]

Let  

\[
m^{x_{0}}=\sum_{k=1}^{2011}m^{x_{k}},\qquad x_{i}\ge 0 .
\]

For \(m=1\) the equation gives \(1=2011\), impossible.  
Hence \(m\ge 2\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  A constructive viewpoint  

Write \(x_{0}=n\;(n\ge 0)\).  
Let  

\[
c_j=\Big|\{k\mid x_k=j\}\Big| ,\qquad j=0,1,2,\ldots
\]

so \(\sum_jc_j=2011\) and  

\[
\sum_{j\ge 0}c_jm^j=m^n. \tag{1}
\]

Begin with the single term \(m^n\).
If we “split’’ a term \(m^t\) into \(m\) terms \(m^{t-1}\) the total
weighted sum is preserved:

\[
m^t= m\cdot m^{t-1}.
\]

Each split increases the number of terms by \(m-1\).
Starting with one term, after \(k\) splits there are  

\[
1+k(m-1)
\]

terms.  Thus to obtain exactly \(2011\) terms we need

\[
1+k(m-1)=2011\quad\Longrightarrow\quad k=\frac{2010}{m-1}. \tag{2}
\]

Hence \(m-1\) must divide \(2010\).
Conversely, if \(m-1\mid2010\) the integer

\[
k=\frac{2010}{m-1}
\]

is non‑negative.  Choosing \(n\ge k\) (e.g. \(n=k\)), we can perform
\(k\) splits as described: repeatedly split a term of positive exponent
until we have performed \(k\) splits.  The total weighted sum remains
\(m^n\), and the number of terms equals \(2011\).  The exponents
\(x_0=n,\;x_1,\ldots,x_{2011}\) are non‑negative integers, giving a
solution of the original equation.

Thus a solution exists **iff** \(m-1\) divides \(2010\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Counting admissible \(m\)

Factor \(2010\):

\[
2010=2\cdot 3\cdot 5\cdot 67 .
\]

All primes are distinct, so the number of positive divisors is  

\[
(1+1)(1+1)(1+1)(1+1)=2^4=16.
\]

Each divisor \(d\) of \(2010\) yields \(m=d+1\;(d\ge 1)\), with
\(2\le m\le 2011\).  
All such \(m\) satisfy the required condition.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{16}
\]
Find the area of the region enclosed by the graph of $|x-60|+|y|=\left|\frac{x}{4}\right|.$

\[
|x-60|+|y|=\Bigl|\frac{x}{4}\Bigr|
\]

We look for the points satisfying the equality first.  
Because the right‑hand side depends only on \(|x|\) and the left on \(|x-60|+|y|\), the region is
symmetric with respect to the \(x\)-axis (the expression contains \(|y|\)).  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Determine the boundary in the first quadrant (\(x\ge 0,\; y\ge 0\))

For \(x\ge 0\) and \(y\ge 0\) the absolute values become

\[
|x-60|+\;y = \frac{x}{4}.
\]

Proceed in two pieces, according to the sign of \(x-60\).

*If \(0\le x < 60\)*  
\[
60-x + y = \frac{x}{4}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad y=\frac{5x}{4}-60 .
\]

*If \(x\ge 60\)*  
\[
x-60 + y = \frac{x}{4}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad y=60-\frac{3x}{4}.
\]

The graph intersects the \(x\)-axis when \(y=0\).  
Solving gives the two intersection points

\[
x=48\quad\text{and}\quad x=80,
\]
hence \((48,0)\) and \((80,0)\).

Between these two x‑values the above equations give the upper boundary.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Lower half of the shape (\(y\le 0\))

Since \(|y|=-y\) for negative \(y\),

\[
|x-60| - y = \frac{x}{4}.
\]

Using the same two pieces for \(x\) gives

\[
y = 60-\frac{5x}{4}\quad (0\le x<60), \qquad
y = \frac{3x}{4}-60\quad (60\le x\le80).
\]

These two lines meet the axis at the same \((48,0)\) and \((80,0)\) and give the lower
boundary.  

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  The closed region

The graph therefore consists of the four straight‑line segments

\[
(48,0)\to(60,15)\to(80,0)\to(60,-15)\to(48,0).
\]

The shape is a symmetric kite (two congruent isosceles triangles; upper and lower
triangles mirror each other).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Area of the region

*Base of each triangle* : \(80-48 = 32\).  
*Height of each triangle* : the vertical distance from the \(x\)-axis to the point
\((60,15)\) (or \((60,-15)\)) is \(15\).

Area of top triangle:
\[
\frac12 \times 32 \times 15 = 240 .
\]

Area of bottom triangle:
\[
240 .
\]

Total area:
\[
240+240 = 480 .
\]

Alternatively, using the shoelace formula on the vertices
\((48,0), (60,15), (80,0), (60,-15)\) gives

\[
\text{Area} = \frac12\bigl|\,(-480)-480\,\bigr| = 480 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{480}
\]

The sequence $\left(z_{n}\right)$ of complex numbers satisfies the following properties: $z_{1}$ and $z_{2}$ are not real. $z_{n+2}=z_{n+1}^{2} z_{n}$ for all integers $n \geq 1$. $\frac{z_{n+3}}{z_{n}^{2}}$ is real for all integers $n \geq 1$. $\left|\frac{z_{3}}{z_{4}}\right|=\left|\frac{z_{4}}{z_{5}}\right|=2$ Find the product of all possible values of $z_{1}$.

The recurrence  

\[
z_{n+2}=z_{n+1}^{2}z_{n}\qquad (n\ge 1)
\]

gives  

\[
z_{n+3}=(z_{n+1}^{2}z_{n})^{2}z_{n+1}=z_{n+1}^{5}z_{n}^{2}\; ,
\]

hence  

\[
\frac{z_{n+3}}{z_{n}^{2}}=z_{n+1}^{5}\quad\text{and so}\quad  
z_{n+1}^{5}\in\mathbb R\;\;(n\ge1).
\]

Therefore both \(z_{1}\) and \(z_{2}\) satisfy \(\displaystyle z_k^{5}\in\mathbb R\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Arguments of \(z_1,\;z_2\)

Write \(z_k=|z_k|\,e^{i\theta_k}\).  
\(z_k^{5}\in\mathbb R\) implies  

\[
5\theta_k\in\pi\mathbb Z\Longrightarrow  
\theta_k=\frac{m_k\pi}{5}\quad (m_k\in\mathbb Z).
\]

Because \(z_1$ and \(z_2$ are **not real**, \(m_1, m_2\) cannot be a multiple of 5.  
Thus \(m_1,m_2\in\{1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9\}\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Moduli of \(z_1,\;z_2\)

From the given equalities  

\[
\left|\frac{z_{3}}{z_{4}}\right|
= \left|\frac{z_{4}}{z_{5}}\right| = 2
\]

compute \(z_3,z_4,z_5\) in terms of \(z_1,z_2\):

\[
z_3 = z_2^2 z_1 ,\qquad  
z_4 = z_2^5 z_1^2 ,\qquad  
z_5 = z_2^{12} z_1^5 .
\]

Hence  

\[
\left|\frac{z_3}{z_4}\right|=\frac{1}{|z_1|\,|z_2|^3}=2,
\qquad
\left|\frac{z_4}{z_5}\right|=\frac{1}{|z_1|^3|z_2|^7}=2.
\]

Let \(a=|z_1|,\;b=|z_2|\).  
The two equations give

\[
ab^3=\tfrac12 ,\qquad a^3b^7=\tfrac12 .
\]

Dividing the second by the first

\[
a^2b^4=1\Longrightarrow a^2=\frac1{b^4} .
\]

Substituting back \(ab^3=\frac12\):

\[
\frac{b}{b^4}= \frac12\Longrightarrow b=\frac12,\qquad a=4 .
\]

Thus \( |z_1|=4,\; |z_2|=\frac12\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Admissible values of \(z_1\)

Using the argument condition \(\theta_1=\frac{m_1\pi}{5}\) with \(m_1\not\equiv0\pmod5\), the eight possible values are  

\[
z_1=4e^{\,i m\pi/5},
\qquad m\in\{1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9\}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Product of all possible \(z_1\)

The product is

\[
\prod_{m\in\{1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9\}} 4e^{\,i m\pi/5}
=4^{8}\,
\exp\!\Bigl(i\frac{\pi}{5}\sum m\Bigr).
\]

\[
\sum_{m=1}^{4}m+\sum_{m=6}^{9}m=(1+2+3+4)+(6+7+8+9)=40,
\]

hence

\[
\exp\!\Bigl(i\frac{\pi}{5}\cdot40\Bigr)=e^{i8\pi}=1 .
\]

Therefore the product simplifies to  

\[
4^{8}=65536 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{65536}
\]

Let  $A_1B_1C_1$ ,  $A_2B_2C_2$ , and  $A_3B_3C_3$  be three triangles in the plane. For  $1 \le i \le3$ , let  $D_i $ ,  $E_i$ , and  $F_i$  be the midpoints of  $B_iC_i$ ,  $A_iC_i$ , and  $A_iB_i$ , respectively. Furthermore, for  $1 \le i \le 3$  let  $G_i$  be the centroid of  $A_iB_iC_i$ .
Suppose that the areas of the triangles  $A_1A_2A_3$ ,  $B_1B_2B_3$ ,  $C_1C_2C_3$ ,  $D_1D_2D_3$ ,  $E_1E_2E_3$ , and  $F_1F_2F_3$  are  $2$ ,  $3$ ,  $4$ ,  $20$ ,  $21$ , and  $2020$ , respectively. Compute the largest possible area of  $G_1G_2G_3$ .

Let  

\[
\mathbf a_i,\mathbf b_i,\mathbf c_i\qquad (i=1,2,3)
\]

be the position vectors of \(A_i,B_i,C_i\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Express the given areas
Define  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf x &= \mathbf a_2-\mathbf a_1,\qquad 
\mathbf x'=\mathbf a_3-\mathbf a_1,\\[2mm]
\mathbf y &= \mathbf b_2-\mathbf b_1,\qquad 
\mathbf y'=\mathbf b_3-\mathbf b_1,\\[2mm]
\mathbf z &= \mathbf c_2-\mathbf c_1,\qquad 
\mathbf z'=\mathbf c_3-\mathbf c_1 .
\end{aligned}
\]

For a planar vector cross product  \(\times \) we have
\[
\operatorname{Area}(PQ R)= \tfrac12\!\left|\overrightarrow{QR}\times\overrightarrow{PR}\right|
\]

and \(\overrightarrow{QR}\times\overrightarrow{PR}\) is linear in each argument.
Thus

\[
\begin{aligned}
| \mathbf x\times\mathbf x'| &= 4 &\text{(area of }A_1A_2A_3),\\
| \mathbf y\times\mathbf y'| &= 6 &\text{(area of }B_1B_2B_3),\\
| \mathbf z\times\mathbf z'| &= 8 \qquad\text{(area of }C_1C_2C_3),
\end{aligned}
\]
and

\[
\begin{aligned}
|(\mathbf y+\mathbf z)\times(\mathbf y'+\mathbf z')| &= 80,\\
|(\mathbf x+\mathbf z)\times(\mathbf x'+\mathbf z')| &= 84,\\
|(\mathbf x+\mathbf y)\times(\mathbf x'+\mathbf y')| &= 8080.
\end{aligned}
\tag{1}
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Translate back to sums of cross products
Expanding the cross products in (1) gives

\[
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf y\times\mathbf z'+\mathbf z\times\mathbf y' &= \pm 80- (6+8)=
   \begin{cases}
     66 \\ -94
   \end{cases}\\[1mm]
\mathbf x\times\mathbf z'+\mathbf z\times\mathbf x' &= \pm 84-(4+8)=
   \begin{cases}
     72 \\ -96
   \end{cases}\\[1mm]
\mathbf x\times\mathbf y'+\mathbf y\times\mathbf x' &= \pm 8080-(4+6)=
   \begin{cases}
     8070 \\ -8090
   \end{cases}
\tag{2}
\end{aligned}
\]

(The ‘\(\pm\)’ appears because only the absolute values are prescribed.)

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Cross product of the sums  
Let  
\[
\mathbf u=\mathbf x+\mathbf y+\mathbf z,\qquad 
\mathbf u'=\mathbf x'+\mathbf y'+\mathbf z'.
\]
Then

\[
\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'=
 \mathbf x\times\mathbf x'+\mathbf y\times\mathbf y'+\mathbf z\times\mathbf z'
 +\bigl(\mathbf x\times\mathbf y'+\mathbf y\times\mathbf x'\bigr)
 +\bigl(\mathbf x\times\mathbf z'+\mathbf z\times\mathbf x'\bigr)
 +\bigl(\mathbf y\times\mathbf z'+\mathbf z\times\mathbf y'\bigr).
\]

Using the known values \(4,6,8\) for the first three terms and the three pairs
from (2), we obtain

\[
\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'
  =18+\sigma_{xy}+\sigma_{xz}+\sigma_{yz},
\]
where \(\sigma_{ij}\) denotes the appropriate pair‐sum chosen from the
two possibilities in (2).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Maximize \(|\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'|\)

We may independently select the sign of each pair‑sum.
Considering the \(2^3=8\) possible sign choices gives

\[
\begin{array}{c|c}
(\sigma_{xy},\sigma_{xz},\sigma_{yz}) & |\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'| \\ \hline
(8070,72,66)   &  8226 \\
(8070,72,-94)   &  8066 \\
(8070,-96,66)  &  8058 \\
(8070,-96,-94) &  7898 \\
(-8090,72,66) &  7934 \\
(-8090,72,-94) &  8094 \\
(-8090,-96,66) &  8102 \\
(-8090,-96,-94) &  8262
\end{array}
\]

The largest magnitude is \(|\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'|=8262\),
obtained when all three pair‑sums are taken with the negative sign.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 5.  Area of \(G_1G_2G_3\)

The centroid of \(\triangle A_iB_iC_i\) is
\[
\mathbf g_i=\frac{\mathbf a_i+\mathbf b_i+\mathbf c_i}{3},
\]
hence
\[
\mathbf g_2-\mathbf g_1=\frac13(\mathbf x+\mathbf y+\mathbf z)=\frac13\mathbf u
\quad\text{and}\quad
\mathbf g_3-\mathbf g_1=\frac13(\mathbf x'+\mathbf y'+\mathbf z')=\frac13\mathbf u'.
\]

Therefore

\[
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Area}(G_1G_2G_3)
  &=\tfrac12\left|\bigl(\mathbf g_2-\mathbf g_1\bigr)\times
                 \bigl(\mathbf g_3-\mathbf g_1\bigr)\right|\\[2mm]
  &=\tfrac12\left|\frac13\,\mathbf u\times\frac13\,\mathbf u'\right|\\[2mm]
  &=\frac{1}{18}\,|\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'|.
\end{aligned}
\]

With the maximal value \(|\mathbf u\times\mathbf u'|=8262\),

\[
\operatorname{Area}(G_1G_2G_3)=\frac{8262}{18}=459 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
\[
\boxed{459}
\]

Andile and Zandre play a game on a  $2017 \times 2017$  board. At the beginning, Andile declares some of the squares *forbidden*, meaning the nothing may be placed on such a square. After that, they take turns to place coins on the board, with Zandre placing the first coin. It is not allowed to place a coin on a forbidden square or in the same row or column where another coin has already been placed. The player who places the last coin wins the game.

What is the least number of squares Andile needs to declare as forbidden at the beginning to ensure a win? (Assume that both players use an optimal strategy.)

First notice that the two players are simply playing the following impartial game

\[
\text{“pick an allowed square, delete its row and its column from future play.”}
\]

Let \(R\) be the set of rows that are still available and let \(C\) be the set of columns that
are still available.  
At any moment the set of moves corresponds to the set of edges of a bipartite graph with
parts \(R\) and \(C\); a move is an edge that is chosen and then both its endpoints are
removed.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  Size of the game

When the graph is finite and bipartite, the game is equivalent to a single Nim heap
whose size is the cardinality of a maximum matching of the graph.  
Indeed, any move deletes one row and one column, therefore the size of a maximum
matching decreases by **exactly one** after every move.  
Consequently the total number of moves that can be made equals the size \(M\) of a
maximum matching of the current graph:
the first player wins iff \(M\) is odd, the second player wins iff \(M\) is even.

For the full \(2017\times2017\) board every pair of a row and a column is allowed,
so the initial graph is \(K_{2017,2017}\) and the maximum matching size is
\(M=2017\;(\text{odd})\).  
Hence, with an unfettered board the first player (Zandre) wins.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  What must \(M\) become for Andile to win?

Andile must make the maximum matching size even.  
The smallest even number that does not exceed 2017 is 2016, so Andile must make
\(M\le 2016\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  How many squares must be forbidden?

Deleting a square \(s=(r,c)\) removes the edge \(\{r,c\}\).
Let us ask: **What is the least number of edges that must be deleted from
\(K_{n,n}\) (\(n=2017\)) so that no perfect matching remains?**

Suppose we delete fewer than \(n\) edges.  
Choose a row \(r\).  Since at most \(n-1\) edges incident with \(r\) are deleted,
there is at least one column \(c\) that still contains the edge \((r,c)\).
Now choose a second row \(r'\ne r\).
Because at most \(n-1\) edges were deleted, the edge \((r',c)\) may still
be present.  By repeating this argument for all rows we can construct a
perfect matching that avoids all deleted edges.  
Thus, if fewer than \(n\) edges are removed, a perfect matching survives.

On the other hand, deleting **all** the \(n\) edges incident to a fixed row
(or, equivalently, to a fixed column) certainly destroys every perfect
matching.  After this deletion we are left with \(n-1\) rows and \(n\) columns,
so the new maximum matching size is \(n-1=2016\).

Hence \(n=2017\) is the *minimal* number of forbidden squares that guarantees
that the maximum matching size drops from \(2017\) to \(2016\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  The strategy

Andile simply forbids all squares in a single row (or all in a single column).
After this move the game is played on a \(2016\times2017\) board, which has a
maximum matching of size \(2016\).
Because \(2016\) is even, the second player (Andile) will always be the one
to make the last move, no matter how optimally Zandre plays.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\boxed{\,2017\,}
\]

Thus the least number of squares that Andile must declare forbidden
at the start to ensure his victory is **2017**.

**(1)  Intersection points**

From the hyperbola  
\[
xy=\frac34 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad y=\frac{3}{4x}\;(x\neq 0)
\]

Insert this in the ellipse  
\[
3x^{2}+y^{2}=3\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
3x^{2}+\Bigl(\frac{3}{4x}\Bigr)^{2}=3 .
\]

Multiplying by \(16x^{2}\),

\[
48x^{4}-48x^{2}+9=0\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
16x^{4}-16x^{2}+3=0 .
\]

Let \(u=x^{2}\).  Then \(16u^{2}-16u+3=0\) and

\[
u=\frac{16\pm 8}{32}=\frac34,\;\frac14 .
\]

Hence \(x^{2}= \dfrac34\) or \(x^{2}= \dfrac14\), i.e.

\[
x=\pm\frac{\sqrt3}{2},\qquad x =\pm\frac12 .
\]

For each value of \(x\), use \(y=\dfrac{3}{4x}\):

\[
\boxed{\begin{aligned}
\left(\frac{\sqrt3}{2},\,\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\right),&
\qquad \left(\frac12,\,\frac32\right),\\[2mm]
\left(-\frac{\sqrt3}{2},\,-\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\right),&
\qquad \left(-\frac12,\,-\frac32\right).
\end{aligned}}
\]

These four points are the only intersection points of \(E\) and \(H\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**(2)  Area of the set**

The inequalities

\[
3x^{2}+y^{2}\le 3 ,\qquad xy\ge \frac34
\]

describe the portions of the ellipse lying in the regions where
\(xy\ge\frac34\).
Because \(xy>0\), the admissible points lie in the first and third
quadrants.  
Symmetry about the origin shows that both lobes have the same area; we
compute the area in the first quadrant and then double it.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
**Area in the first quadrant**

For \(x>0\) the boundary curves are  

\[
y_{\text{ellipse}}=\sqrt{3-3x^{2}}=\sqrt3\,\sqrt{1-x^{2}},\qquad
y_{\text{hyperbola}}=\frac{3}{4x}.
\]

The two curves meet at  
\(x=\frac12\) and \(x=\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\).  
Hence for \(\frac12\le x\le\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\) we have
\(y_{\text{ellipse}}>y_{\text{hyperbola}}\), and the required
area \(A_{1}\) is

\[
A_{1}= \int_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}
\Bigl(\sqrt{3-3x^{2}}-\frac{3}{4x}\Bigr)\,dx .
\]

---

*First integral*

\[
\int_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}\sqrt{3-3x^{2}}\;dx
= \sqrt3\int_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}\sqrt{1-x^{2}}\;dx
= \sqrt3\Bigl[\tfrac12\bigl(x\sqrt{1-x^{2}}+\arcsin x\bigr)\Bigr]
_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}
= \sqrt3\left(\frac{\pi}{12}\right)
= \frac{\pi\sqrt3}{12}.
\]

*Second integral*

\[
\int_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}\frac{3}{4x}\,dx
= \frac34\bigl[\ln x\bigr]_{\frac12}^{\frac{\sqrt3}{2}}
= \frac34\ln\!\left(\frac{\sqrt3/2}{1/2}\right)
= \frac34\ln\!\bigl(\sqrt3\bigr)
= \frac{3}{8}\ln 3.
\]

Consequently

\[
A_{1}= \frac{\pi\sqrt3}{12}-\frac{3}{8}\ln 3 .
\]

Because the region in the third quadrant is a mirror image, the
total area \(A\) is

\[
\boxed{A=2A_{1}= \frac{\pi\sqrt3}{6}-\frac{3}{4}\ln 3 }.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

**Answer**

(1) \( \displaystyle \left(\frac{\sqrt3}{2},\!\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\right),\;
\left(\frac12,\!\frac32\right),\;
\left(-\frac{\sqrt3}{2},\!-\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\right),\;
\left(-\frac12,\!-\frac32\right).\)

(2)  \(\displaystyle A=\frac{\pi\sqrt3}{6}-\frac{3}{4}\ln 3.\)

A8 The band gap of pure silicon is $E_{\mathrm{g}}=1.11 \mathrm{eV}$. Calculate the efficiency, $\eta_{\mathrm{Si}}$, of a silicon solar cell using this
value.

For a crystalline–silicon solar cell the maximum efficiency that can be achieved strictly by the detailed‑balance (Shockley–Queisser) limit is that of a single‑junction cell with a band‑gap of 1.11 eV.  Using the AM 1.5 G spectrum that limit is

\[
\eta _{\mathrm{Si}}\;\simeq\;0.29\;-\;0.30\;\;(\hbox{or }\;29\text{–}30\%).
\]

In other words, even an ideal Si cell can convert only about one‑third of the incident solar power into electricity; practical devices typically reach efficiencies of 25–27 % today.

Triangle $ABC$ is isosceles with $AC = BC$ and $\angle ACB = 106^\circ.$ Point $M$ is in the interior of the triangle so that $\angle MAC = 7^\circ$ and $\angle MCA = 23^\circ.$ Find the number of degrees in $\angle CMB.$

\[
\begin{array}{l}
\text{Let } \triangle ABC \text{ be isosceles with } AC=BC ,\ \angle ACB=106^\circ .
\end{array}
\]

Hence the base angles of \(ABC\) are  

\[
\angle CAB=\angle CBA=\frac{180^\circ-106^\circ}{2}=37^\circ .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Angles at \(M\)

Point \(M\) is inside the triangle and  

\[
\angle MAC=7^\circ,\qquad \angle MCA=23^\circ .
\]

Therefore in \(\triangle AMC\)

\[
\angle AMC=180^\circ-7^\circ-23^\circ=150^\circ .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Find \(\angle BCM\)

At vertex \(C\) the ray \(CM\) makes \(23^\circ\) with \(CA\);  
hence

\[
\angle BCM= \angle ACB-\angle MCA=106^\circ-23^\circ=83^\circ .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Express the sides \(CM,\ BC\)

In \(\triangle AMC\) (law of sines)

\[
\frac{CM}{\sin 7^\circ}=\frac{AC}{\sin150^\circ}
   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad CM=2\,AC\sin 7^\circ .
\]

In \(\triangle ABC\), the equal angles at \(A\) and \(B\) give

\[
BC=AC.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Use \(\triangle BMC\)

Let  

\[
\angle CMB = x \quad (\;0<x<180^\circ\;).
\]

Triangle \(BMC\) has angles  

\[
\angle C = 83^\circ ,\qquad \angle M = x ,\qquad
\angle B = 180^\circ-83^\circ-x = 97^\circ-x .
\]

Applying the law of sines in \(BMC\):

\[
\frac{BC}{\sin x}=\frac{CM}{\sin(97^\circ-x)} .
\]

Insert \(BC=AC\) and \(CM=2AC\sin7^\circ\) and cancel \(AC\):

\[
\frac{1}{\sin x}= \frac{2\sin7^\circ}{\sin(97^\circ-x)}
      \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
      \sin(97^\circ-x)=2\sin7^\circ\sin x .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### Solve for \(x\)

Use \( \sin(97^\circ-x)=\sin(90^\circ+7^\circ-x)=\cos(7^\circ-x) \) and  
the product–to–sum identity \(2\sin a\sin b=\cos(a-b)-\cos(a+b)\):

\[
\cos(7^\circ-x)=\cos(7^\circ-x)-\cos(7^\circ+x).
\]

Hence

\[
\cos(7^\circ+x)=0.
\]

Thus \(7^\circ+x =90^\circ\) (the other solutions give angles outside
\(0^\circ< x<97^\circ\)), so

\[
x = 83^\circ .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------

\[
\boxed{ \angle CMB = 83^\circ }
\]

A container in the shape of a right circular cone is 12 inches tall and its base has a 5-inch radius. The liquid that is sealed inside is 9 inches deep when the cone is held with its point down and its base horizontal. When the liquid is held with its point up and its base horizontal, the height of the liquid is $m - n\sqrt [3]{p},$ where $m,$ $n,$ and $p$ are positive integers and $p$ is not divisible by the cube of any prime number. Find $m + n + p$ .

Let the height of the cone be \(H=12\) in. and its base radius \(R=5\) in.

---

### 1.  Volume of liquid when the cone is point‑down

When the cone is point down the liquid occupies a smaller cone of height \(h=9\) in.  
The radius of that small cone is proportional to the height:

\[
r_1 = R\frac{h}{H} = 5\frac{9}{12} = \frac{15}{4}.
\]

The volume of liquid is

\[
V = \frac13\pi r_1^2 h = \frac13\pi \left(\frac{15}{4}\right)^2(9)
   = \frac{2025}{48}\pi .
\]

---

### 2.  Find the liquid depth when the cone is point‑up

Now the cone’s point is at the top.  
Let the liquid extend a distance \(d\) upward from the flat bottom of the cone (the
base).  
We will calculate \(d\).

Set up coordinates with the tip at \(z=0\) and the base at \(z=12\).  
The radius at height \(z\) is

\[
r(z)=\frac{R}{H}\,z=\frac{5}{12}z .
\]

The liquid occupies a frustum whose lower radius is \(R=5\) (at
\(z=12\)) and whose upper radius is

\[
r_u = r(12-d)=\frac{5}{12}(12-d)=\frac{5}{12}z_c,
\]

with \(z_c=12-d\).

The height of the frustum is \(d=12-z_c\).

The volume of a frustum is
\[
V=\frac{\pi d}{3}\left( R^2+R r_u + r_u^2 \right).
\]

Substituting \(R=5\), \(r_u=\tfrac52\,\frac{z_c}{6}\), and
\(d=12-z_c\), and equating this to the liquid volume obtained earlier:

\[
\frac{\pi(12-z_c)}{3}\!\left[\,25+5\!\left(\frac{5}{12}z_c\right)
+\!\left(\frac{5}{12}z_c\right)^2\right]
       =\frac{2025}{48}\pi .
\]

After canceling \(\pi\), simplifying, and clearing denominators:

\[
(12-z_c)\left(z_c^2+12z_c+144\right)=729   \quad\Longrightarrow\quad
1728-z_c^3 = 729.
\]

Thus

\[
z_c^3 = 999 = 27\!\times 37,
\qquad z_c =\sqrt[3]{999}=3\sqrt[3]{37}.
\]

The depth of the liquid measured from the bottom is

\[
d = 12 - z_c = 12 - 3\sqrt[3]{37}.
\]

---

### 3.  Expressing the answer

The depth is given as
\[
m - n\sqrt[3]{p}\quad\text{with}\quad m=12,\; n=3,\; p=37.
\]

All conditions are satisfied: \(p\) is not divisible by the cube of any prime.

Hence

\[
m+n+p = 12+3+37 = \boxed{52}.
\]

In a certain country  $10\%$  of the employees get  $90\%$  of the total salary paid in this country. Supposing that the country is divided in several regions, is it possible that in every region the total salary of any 10% of the employees is no greater than  $11\%$  of the total salary paid in this region?

**Answer – no.**

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 1.  Re‑express the data

Assume that the country has \(N\) employees and total salary \(S\).
Let

* \(H\) – the set of the *very* highest earners,  
  \( |H| = 0.10\,N\);

* \(L=\text{complement of }H\) – the other 90 % of employees.

We know that

\[
\sum_{i\in H}c_i =0.90\, S , \qquad   
\sum_{i\in L}c_i =0.10\, S .
\tag{1}
\]

Thus the average salary of a worker in \(H\) is 9 times larger
than the average salary of a worker in \(L\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 2.  A concrete numerical model

To keep the argument simple, replace the salaries only by
two numbers that satisfy (1).  
Take the salaries

\[
c_i=\begin{cases}
81&\text{if }\,i\in H,\\[2mm]
1 &\text{if }\,i\in L .
\end{cases}
\]

With 10 % of the workers paid 81 and the rest paid 1 we have

\[
10\cdot 81 = 9\cdot (10\cdot 81)+9\cdot 90
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad 0.90S=10\cdot81,\; 0.10S =90,
\]
so the two numbers satisfy (1).

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 3.  What would a region look like?

Let a region contain \(n\) employees.
Let \(h\) be the number of employees from the high–salary
set \(H\) that belong to this region and let
\(l=n-h\) be the number of employees from \(L\) that belong to it.
The total salary in the region is therefore

\[
T = 81h + 1\cdot l = 81h + n-h = 80h + n .
\tag{2}
\]

The **top 10 % of the region** consists of the \(0.1\,n\) employees
with largest salaries.
Two cases are possible.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### Case A.  \(h\le 0.1\,n\)

All high earners are in that top fraction; we must also take
\(0.1\,n-h\) low–salary employees to fill the top 10 %.  
Thus the salary of the top decile is

\[
T_{10} = 81h + (0.1\,n-h)\cdot 1
= 80h + 0.1\,n .
\tag{3}
\]

The required condition (the salary of the top 10 % ≤ 11 % of the
region’s total) gives

\[
80h + 0.1\,n \;\le\; 0.11\,T
=0.11\,(80h+n)
=8.8h+0.11\,n .
\]

Re‑arranged,

\[
71.2\,h \;\le\; 0.01\,n,
\qquad\text{hence}\qquad
\frac{h}{n}\;\le\; \frac{0.01}{71.2}\approx 1.4\times10^{-4}.
\tag{4}
\]

So **in any region the fraction of high–salary employees may be no
larger than \(0.014\%\) if \(h\le0.1n\).**

--------------------------------------------------------------------
#### Case B.  \(h>0.1\,n\)

Now the top decile consists of \(0.1\,n\) high earners.
Its salary is therefore

\[
T_{10}=0.1\,n\cdot81=8.1\,n .
\]

The inequality becomes

\[
8.1\,n\;\le\;0.11\,T
=0.11\,(80h+n)=8.8h+0.11\,n ,
\]

which gives

\[
h\;\ge\;\frac{7.99}{8.8}\,n\;>\;0.9\,n .
\tag{5}
\]

Thus **in any region more than \(90\%\) of its employees would
have to be high earners**, which is impossible because globally
only \(10\%\) of the employees are high earners.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 4.  Consequence for a partition of the whole country

No region can contain any high‑salary employee unless its size is
extra‑large, but with the global constraint that the country
has only \(10\%\) high earners, at least one region would have
to possess more than \(0.014\%\) (or even more than \(90\%\))
good employees – a contradiction.

More concretely, the total number of high‑salary employees in all
the regions cannot exceed

\[
\sum_{\text{regions}}\frac{0.0014}{100}\;N \;<\;\; 0.01\,N ,
\]

whereas there are exactly \(0.1\,N\) such employees.  Hence no
partition of the country can satisfy the demand that **in every
region the salaries of any 10 % of its employees be at most 11 % of
the region’s total salary**.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.  Final statement

Therefore **it is impossible** to divide the country into regions so
that the two conditions (overall inequality and the 11 % bound in
every region) hold simultaneously.  The extreme inequality in the
whole country cannot be smoothed out by any partition.

Circle $C$ with radius 2 has diameter $\overline{AB}$ . Circle $D$ is internally tangent to circle $C$ at $A$ . Circle $E$ is internally tangent to circle $C$ , externally tangent to circle $D$ , and tangent to $\overline{AB}$ . The radius of circle $D$ is three times the radius of circle $E$ , and can be written in the form $\sqrt{m}-n$ , where $m$ and $n$ are positive integers. Find $m+n$ .

Let the center of the large circle \(C\) be the origin \(O(0,0)\).
Choose the diameter \(AB\) to be horizontal, so that  

\[
A(-2,0),\qquad B(2,0)
\]

because the radius of \(C\) is \(2\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Circle \(D\)

Circle \(D\) is internally tangent to \(C\) at \(A\).
If \(r_D\) is the radius of \(D\), its center \(O_D\) lies on the line from
\(O\) to \(A\) and satisfies

\[
OO_D = 2-r_D .
\]

Hence  

\[
O_D=(-\,(\,2-r_D\,),\,0)=-(2-r_D,0).
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Circle \(E\)

Let \(k=r_E\) (the radius of \(E\)).  
Its center \(O_E=(x,k)\) because \(E\) is tangent to the line \(AB\) (the
\(x\)-axis) a distance \(k\) above it.

* \(E\) is internally tangent to \(C\)  
  \[
  OO_E = 2-k\quad\Longrightarrow\quad x^{2}+k^{2}=(2-k)^{2}.
  \tag{1}
  \]

* \(E\) is externally tangent to \(D\)  
  \[
  OO_D_OE = r_D+r_E=3k+k=4k.
  \]

  Using \(O_D=(3k-2,0)\) (since \(r_D=3k\)), we get  

  \[
  (x-3k+2)^{2}+k^{2}= (4k)^{2}.
  \tag{2}
  \]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Solving for \(k\)

From (1):

\[
x^{2}=4-4k.
\tag{3}
\]

Using (2) and substituting \(x^{2}\) from (3) gives

\[
(4-4k) -2x(3k-2)+(3k-2)^{2}+k^{2}=16k^{2}.
\]

After simplifying the terms, one obtains

\[
x(3k-2)= -3k^{2}-8k+4. \tag{4}
\]

Thus

\[
x=\frac{-3k^{2}-8k+4}{\,3k-2\,}. \tag{5}
\]

Equating (3) with \(x^{2}\) from (5) yields

\[
(3k^{2}+8k-4)^{2}=(4-4k)(9k^{2}-12k+4).
\]

Solving this quartic simplifies to

\[
k^{2}\left(9k^{2}+84k-44\right)=0,
\]

so, for a positive radius,

\[
9k^{2}+84k-44=0.
\]

Hence

\[
k=\frac{-84+24\sqrt{15}}{18}
   =\frac{-14+4\sqrt{15}}{3}.
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Radius of circle \(D\)

\[
r_D=3k = -14 + 4\sqrt{15}
      = \sqrt{240}-14 .
\]

Thus \(r_D\) is in the required form \(\sqrt{m}-n\) with  

\[
m=240,\qquad n=14 .
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 5.  Desired sum

\[
m+n = 240+14 = \boxed{254}.
\]
Given integer  $m\geq2$ , $x_1,...,x_m$  are non-negative real numbers,prove that:  $$ (m-1)^{m-1}(x_1^m+...+x_m^m)\geq(x_1+...+x_m)^m-m^mx_1...x_m $$  and please find out when the equality holds.

\[
\text{let }m\ge 2,\qquad x_{1},\ldots ,x_{m}\ge 0 .          
\]

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 1.  Normalising the variables  

Put  

\[
S=x_{1}+x_{2}+\dots +x_{m}\qquad   (S\ge 0),\qquad     
y_{i}=\frac{x_{i}}{S}\;(i=1,\dots ,m),
\]

so that  

\[
y_{i}\ge 0 ,\qquad \sum_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}=1,
\qquad
x_{i}=Sy_{i},\qquad 
\prod_{i=1}^{m}x_{i}=S^{m}\prod_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}.
\]

The inequality  

\[
(m-1)^{\,m-1}(x_{1}^{m}+\cdots+x_{m}^{m})\ge  
(S)^{m}-m^{m}\prod_{i=1}^{m}x_{i}
\]

becomes, after dividing by \(S^{m}\;(S>0)\),

\[
\boxed{(m-1)^{\,m-1}\sum_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}^{\,m}+m^{m}\prod_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}\;\ge\;1}
\tag{1}
\]

(the case \(S=0\) – all \(x_{i}=0\) – is trivial).  
Thus we have to minimise the function

\[
F(y_{1},\dots ,y_{m})=
(m-1)^{\,m-1}\sum_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}^{\,m}+m^{m}\prod_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}
\]

under the condition \(y_{1}+\dots +y_{m}=1,\; y_{i}\ge 0\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 2.  Where is the minimum attained  

Because the objective function is continuous, a minimum exists on the
compact simplex \(\{y\mid y\ge0,\sum y=1\}\).
If some \(y_{j}=0\) the product vanishes and the function reduces to

\[
F(y)= (m-1)^{m-1}\sum_{i=1}^{m}y_{i}^{\,m}.
\]

Let \(k\ge 1\) be the number of non‑zero \(y_{i}\)’s.
For fixed \(k\) the minimum of \(\sum y_{i}^{\,m}\) is achieved when all
the \(k\) positive \(y_{i}\)’s are equal, i.e. \(y_{i}=1/k\) for those
indices.  Then

\[
F_{\min}(k) = (m-1)^{m-1}\,k\,\Bigl(\frac 1k\Bigr)^{\!m}
            = (m-1)^{m-1}\,k^{\,1-m}.                                     
\tag{2}
\]

The function \(k^{\,1-m}\) decreases when \(k\) grows, so in
(2) the smallest value is obtained for the largest possible \(k\), i.e.
\(k=m-1\).  
For \(k=m-1\),

\[
F_{\min} = (m-1)^{m-1}\,(m-1)^{\,1-m}=1 .
\tag{3}
\]

Thus the minimum of \(F\) on the boundary (with at least one zero) is
equal to \(1\).

Now suppose all \(y_{i}>0\).  We look for a stationary point of \(F\)
under the linear restriction \(\sum y_{i}=1\).  Using Lagrange
multipliers,

\[
\frac{\partial}{\partial y_{i}}
\Bigl[
(m-1)^{m-1}\sum y_{j}^{\,m}+m^{m}\prod y_{j} 
-\lambda\Bigl(\sum y_{j}-1\Bigr)\Bigr]
=0 ,
\quad i=1,\dots ,m .
\]

The derivative equals  

\[
(m-1)^{m-1}\,m\,y_{i}^{\,m-1}+m^{m}
\frac{\prod_{j=1}^{m}y_{j}}{y_{i}}-\lambda .
\]

Hence for any \(i,j\),

\[
(m-1)^{m-1}\,m\,y_{i}^{\,m-1}
+ m^{m}\frac{\prod y}{y_{i}}
=
(m-1)^{m-1}\,m\,y_{j}^{\,m-1}
+ m^{m}\frac{\prod y}{y_{j}} .
\]

This forces \(y_{i}=y_{j}\) for all \(i,j\); consequently the only
critical point inside the simplex is

\[
y_{1}=y_{2}=\dots =y_{m}= \frac 1m .
\]

For this point

\[
F\Bigl(\tfrac{1}{m},\dots ,\tfrac{1}{m}\Bigr)
   =(m-1)^{m-1}\,m\Bigl(\frac1m\Bigr)^{\!m}+m^{m}\Bigl(\frac1m\Bigr)^{\!m}
   =\Bigl(\frac{m-1}{m}\Bigr)^{m-1}+1>1 .
\]

Thus every interior critical point gives a value larger than the
boundary minimum.  Hence the global minimum of \(F\) is \(1\),
and it is attained only on the boundary when \(k=m-1\).

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 3.  Equality cases  

Condition \(k=m-1\) means: precisely one of the numbers \(y_{i}\)
is zero, and the remaining \(m-1\) are equal to \(1/(m-1)\).
Going back to the original variables:

* either \(x_{1}=x_{2}=\dots =x_{m}=0\)  (the trivial case \(S=0\));

or

* exactly one of the \(x_{i}\)’s equals \(0\), the other \(m-1\) values
  are equal:  

  \[
  x_{1}=x_{2}=\dots =x_{m-1}=a>0,\qquad x_{m}=0
  \]
  (and any permutation of the indices).

Indeed, for such a vector

\[
(m-1)^{m-1}\!\sum_{i=1}^{m}x_{i}^{m}
   =(m-1)^{m-1}\,(m-1)a^{m}
   =(m-1)^{m}a^{m}
\]

and

\[
\bigl(x_{1}+x_{2}+\dots +x_{m}\bigr)^{m}-m^{m}x_{1}x_{2}\dots x_{m}
  =(m-1)^{m}a^{m}\;,
\]

so equality holds.

--------------------------------------------------------------------
### 4.  Final statement  

For all integers \(m\ge 2\) and all non‑negative real numbers
\(x_{1},\dots ,x_{m}\),

\[
\boxed{\;(m-1)^{\,m-1}\bigl(x_{1}^{m}+x_{2}^{m}+\dots +x_{m}^{m}\bigr)
     \;\ge\;
     \bigl(x_{1}+x_{2}+\dots +x_{m}\bigr)^{m}
     \;-\;m^{m} x_{1}x_{2}\dots x_{m}\;}
\]

and equality occurs if and only if

* all \(x_{i}=0\);  
  or  
* exactly one of the \(x_{i}\)’s is \(0\) and the remaining
  \(m-1\) numbers are equal.  

(Any permutation of the indices is allowed.)

The inequality is strict whenever none of the above equality
configurations is satisfied.
